TemplateCategory.Name: 1-key
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates are composed of a single key. If any of these templates conflict with single letter variables that you use frequently, you can move them individually to a disabled folder, or you can disable all templates in this category by clicking the green check box to the left of the "1-key" category node.

TemplateCategory.Name: Properties
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates declare properties. This category contains subcategories for declaring read-only and write-only templates.

TemplateCategory.Name: Read-only
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates declare read-only properties. Templates in this category start with the letter "rp" and are followed by a short mnemonic that represents the type of property to create. Most of these templates declare fields for the property as well, taking advantage of linked identifier technology, which links property names to their corresponding fields. To declare a property without a field variable, end the template with a comma before expanding (comma at the end means you'll get "a shorter version of the template").

TemplateCategory.Name: Generics
TemplateCategory.Comments:
Templates for declaring read-only properties of a generic type. These templates start with "rp", are followed by the mnemonic for the generic type (e.g., "l" for List, "q" for Queue, "s" for Stack, "d" for Dictionary, etc.) and then a dot, like this:
rpl. rps. rpq. rpd.
While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonic for the type parameter to the generic, like this:
rpl.i rpq.s
Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
rpd.i,b

Template.Name: rp?Generic1Type?.
Template.Comment: Declares a property of the specified one-parameter generic type. Letters following the "p" specify the generic. This template allows you to specify the generic parameter type after expansion. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new generic types.

Template.Comment: Declares a property of the specified one-parameter generic type. Letters following the "p" specify the generic. This template allows you to specify the generic parameter type after expansion. Use the Core\Aliases\Dynamic Lists options page to add new generic types.

TemplateCategory.Name: Write-only
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates declare write-only properties. Templates in this category start with the letters "wp" and are followed by a short mnemonic that represents the type of write-only property to create. Most of these templates declare fields for the property as well, taking advantage of linked identifier technology, which links property names to their corresponding fields. To declare a write-only property without a field variable, end the template with a comma before expanding (comma at the end means you'll get "a shorter version of the template").

TemplateCategory.Name: Generics
TemplateCategory.Comments:
Templates for declaring write-only properties of a generic type. These templates start with "wp", are followed by the mnemonic for the generic type (e.g., "l" for List, "q" for Queue, "s" for Stack, "d" for Dictionary, etc.) and then a dot, like this:
wpl. wps. wpq. wpd.
While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonic for the type parameter to the generic, like this:
wpl.i wpq.s
Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
wpd.i,b

TemplateCategory.Name: Exceptions
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates build custom exception classes. You can use the "ex" template by itself, or follow it up with one or two letters to indicate the type of a custom property to add to the exception class. For example, "exs" will create a custom exception descendant with a string property.

Expansion.Body:
''' <summary> ''' «Marker» ''' </summary> <Serializable> _ Public Class «:#ExceptionNameSelected#» Inherits Exception
#Region "private fields..." Private «:#ExceptionFieldName#» As «:#GenericTypeNoArgsWithTextField#» #End Region
«:#ExceptionConstructor#» #Region "«:#ExceptionName#»(ByVal message As String, ByVal «:#ExceptionParamName#» As «:#GenericTypeNoArgs#»)" ''' <summary> ''' Constructs a new «:#ExceptionName#». ''' </summary> ''' <param name="message">The exception message</param> ''' <param name="«:#ExceptionParamName#»">The value for the «Link(Value)» property.</param> Public Sub New(ByVal message As String, ByVal «:#ExceptionParamName#» As «:#GenericTypeNoArgs#») MyBase.New(message) Me.«:#ExceptionFieldName#» = «:#ExceptionParamName#» End Sub #End Region #Region "«:#ExceptionName#»(ByVal message As String, ByVal «:#ExceptionParamName#» As «:#GenericTypeNoArgs#», ByVal innerException As Exception)" ''' <summary> ''' Constructs a new «:#ExceptionName#». ''' </summary> ''' <param name="message">The exception message.</param> ''' <param name="«:#ExceptionParamName#»">The value for the «Link(Value)» property.</param> ''' <param name="innerException">The inner exception.</param> Public Sub New(ByVal message As String, ByVal «:#ExceptionParamName#» As «:#GenericTypeNoArgs#», ByVal innerException As Exception) MyBase.New(message, innerException) Me.«:#ExceptionFieldName#» = «:#ExceptionParamName#» End Sub #End Region #Region "«:#ExceptionName#»(ByVal info As SerializationInfo, ByVal context As StreamingContext)" ''' <summary> ''' Serialization constructor. ''' </summary> Protected Sub New(ByVal info As SerializationInfo, ByVal context As StreamingContext) MyBase.New(info, context) Me.«:#ExceptionFieldName#» = DirectCast(info.GetValue("«Link(Value)»", GetType(«:#GenericTypeNoArgs#»)), «:#GenericTypeNoArgs#») End Sub #End Region
' public methods... #Region "GetObjectData" ''' <summary> ''' Overridden method from the ISerializable interface, to include the additional fields in serialization. ''' </summary> <SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, SerializationFormatter := true)> _ Public Overrides Sub GetObjectData(ByVal info As SerializationInfo, ByVal context As StreamingContext) MyBase.GetObjectData(info, context) info.AddValue("«Link(Value)»", «Link(Value)») End Sub #End Region
' public properties... #Region "Message" ''' <summary> ''' Overridden property from System.Exception, to include the additional fields in the message. ''' </summary> Public Overrides Readonly Property Message As String Get Return String.Format(CultureInfo.CurrentCulture, "{0}, «Link(Value)»: {1}", MyBase.Message, «Link(Value)») End Get End Property #End Region #Region "«Link(Value)»" ''' <summary> ''' «Marker» ''' </summary> Public Readonly Property «Link(Value)» As «:#GenericTypeNoArgs#» Get Return «:#ExceptionFieldName#» End Get End Property #End Region End Class

''' </summary> Protected Sub New(ByVal info As SerializationInfo, ByVal context As StreamingContext) MyBase.New(info, context) Me.«:#ExceptionFieldName#» = DirectCast(info.GetValue("«Link(Value)»", GetType(«:#ExceptionFieldType#»)), «:#ExceptionFieldType#») End Sub #End Region

TemplateCategory.Name: Generics
TemplateCategory.Comments:
Templates for declaring methods that return generic types. These templates start with an "m", are followed by the mnemonic for the generic type (e.g., "l" for List, "q" for Queue, "s" for Stack, "d" for Dictionary, etc.) and then a dot, like this:
ml. ms. mq. md.
While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonic for the type parameter to the generic, like this:
ml.i mq.s
Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
md.i,b

TemplateCategory.Name: Read/Write
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates declare properties. Templates in this category start with the letter "p" and are followed by a short mnemonic that represents the type of property to create. Most of these templates declare fields for the property as well, taking advantage of linked identifier technology, which links property names to their corresponding fields. To declare a property without a field variable, end the template with a comma before expanding (comma at the end means you'll get "a shorter version of the template").

TemplateCategory.Name: Generics
TemplateCategory.Comments:
Templates for declaring read/write properties of a generic type. These templates start with "p", are followed by the mnemonic for the generic type (e.g., "l" for List, "q" for Queue, "s" for Stack, "d" for Dictionary, etc.) and then a dot, like this:
pl. ps. pq. pd.
While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonic for the type parameter to the generic, like this:
pl.i pq.s
Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
pd.i,b

TemplateCategory.Name: Read-only
TemplateCategory.Comments: These templates declare read-only properties. Templates in this category start with the letter "r" and are followed by a short mnemonic that represents the type of read-only property to create. Most of these templates declare fields for the property as well, taking advantage of linked identifier technology, which links property names to their corresponding fields. To declare a read-only property without a field variable, end the template with a comma before expanding (comma at the end means you'll get "a shorter version of the template").

TemplateCategory.Name: Create on Demand
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates for creating properties that initialize a variable based on demand.

''' <summary> ''' Gets the «Link(«?PropertyNameFromField(«?Paste»)»)». ''' </summary> Public ReadOnly Property «Caret»«Link(«?PropertyNameFromField(«?Paste»)»)»«BlockAnchor» As «PasteType» Get ' Create on demand... If «?Paste» Is Nothing «?Paste» = New «PasteType»(«Marker») End If
Return «?Paste» End Get End Property

Template.Name: rpcod
Template.Comment: Public Property, Read-only, Create-on-demand.

Expansion.Body: Public ReadOnly Property «Cursor»«Paste» As «PasteType» Get If «Paste» Is Nothing Then «Paste» = New «PasteType»() End If Return «Paste» End Get End Property

TemplateCategory.Name: Generics
TemplateCategory.Comments:
Templates for declaring read-only properties of a generic type. These templates start with "r", are followed by the mnemonic for the generic type (e.g., "l" for List, "q" for Queue, "s" for Stack, "d" for Dictionary, etc.) and then a dot, like this:
rl. rs. rq. rd.
While the example templates above will expand, you can optionally follow this mnemonic with a mnemonic for the type parameter to the generic, like this:
rl.i rq.s
Some generics accept two type parameters. You can declare those by separating the types with a comma, like this:
rd.i,b

TemplateCategory.Name: Serialization
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate code to make easier to write serialization code. The "is" template generates the needed methods to implement ISerializable, and the "av" (AddValue) and "gv" (GetValue) templates are used to move data between the stream and a field identifier on the clipboard.

Template.Name: is
Template.Comment: Implements ISerializable

TemplateCategory.Name: Program Blocks
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate program blocks that can be used inside methods and property accessors.

TemplateCategory.Name: Else blocks
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate Else blocks. Nearly all of these templates start with the letter "l". Many of these templates string together powerful combos. For example, "sn" sets the identifier on the clipboard to Nothing. "lsn" creates the "Else" keyword, and then sets the identifier on the clipboard to Nothing.

TemplateCategory.Name: Flow
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate code that controls program flow. This includes loops (While, For, For Each, etc.), Select statements, and flow breakage (e.g., throw exceptions, Return, Exit, etc.).

Template.Comment: Generates a Case block -- called from the switch template.

TemplateCategory.Name: Regions
TemplateCategory.Comments: Templates in this category generate common regions. Nearly all of these templates start with "re", and are followed by a few letters that describe the region to create. This category also includes "er", a template that generates an #End Region directive. Note: CodeRush includes an AutoRegion command (by default bound to Ctrl+3), that will create a region around the current property, method, or event.

Template.Name: <ai
Template.Comment: Apply this attribute to your test method to replace the CurrentPrincipal with another role.

Template.Name: <ar
Template.Comment: Apply this attribute to your test method to automatically create a TransactionScope that is rolled back when the test is finished.

Template.Name: <cd
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming from a class which must implement IEnumerable<object[]>.

Template.Name: <ed
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming a Microsoft Excel (.xls) spreadsheet.

Expansion.Body: <ExcelData(«Caret»«Field(FileName,The filename of the XLS spreadsheet file.)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(SelectStatement,The SELECT statement that returns the data for the theory)»)>«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: <f
Template.Comment: Attribute that is applied to a method to indicate that it is a fact that should be run by the test runner. It can also be extended to support a customized definition of a test method.

Template.Name: <fc
Template.Comment: Apply this attribute to your test method to freeze the time represented by the Clock class.

Expansion.Body: <FreezeClock(«Caret»«Field(year,The frozen year)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(month,The frozen month)», «Field(day,The frozen day)»)>«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: <id
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming from inline values.

Expansion.Body: <InlineData(«Caret»«Field(DataValues,The data values to pass to the theory)»«BlockAnchor»)>«FinalTarget»
<OleDbData(«Caret»«Field(connectionString,The OLEDB connection string to the data)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(selectStatement,The SELECT statement used to return the data for the theory)»)>«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: <pd
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming from a public static property on the test class. The property must return IEnumerable<object[]> with the test data.

Expansion.Body: <PropertyData(«Caret»«Field(PropertyName,The name of the public static property on the test class that will provide the test data)»«BlockAnchor»)> «FinalTarget»

Template.Name: <rw
Template.Comment: Attributes used to decorate a test fixture that is run with an alternate test runner. The test runner must implement the ITestClassCommand interface.

Template.Name: <ssd
Template.Comment: Provides a data source for a data theory, with the data coming a Microsoft SQL Server.

Expansion.Body: <SqlServerData(«Caret»«Field(serverName,The server name of the Microsoft SQL Server)»«BlockAnchor», «Field(databaseName,The database name)», «Field(selectStatement,The SQL SELECT statement to return the data for the data theory)»)>«FinalTarget»

Template.Name: <t
Template.Comment: Attribute used to decorate a test method with arbitrary name/value pairs ("traits").

Template.Name: <th
Template.Comment: Marks a test method as being a data theory. Data theories are tests which are fed various bits of data from a data source, mapping to parameters on the test method. If the data source contains multiple rows, then the test method is executed multiple times (once with each data row).

Template.Name: <tr
Template.Comment: Apply to a test method to trace the method begin and end.
